title: Widows Run for Congress After Husbands’ Covid-19 Deaths
sub_head: Susan Wright and Julia Letlow compete in elections to fill two House seats
body:
WASHINGTON—Widows replacing their late husbands once was a common path for women to enter Congress, but the practice dwindled over time. This year, the coronavirus pandemic might bring it back.
Susan Wright, the wife of the late Rep. Ron Wright, said Wednesday she would run for the Texas Republican’s seat, the second widow to announce a House campaign this year. She follows Julia Letlow, the spouse of late Rep.-elect Luke Letlow (R., La.), who announced her candidacy last month.
While dozens of lawmakers have been sickened by Covid-19 since last March, Messrs. Wright and Letlow are the only congressmen or congressmen-elect to die after contracting it.
“I’m running for Congress to continue my husband’s legacy by supporting economic growth, reforming our broken healthcare system, and defending Texas conservative values,” Mrs. Wright said Wednesday, announcing her campaign. A former training director for airlines, Mrs. Wright also worked as a district director for two members of the Texas state House.
Mr. Wright died earlier this month at the age of 67, at the start of his second term in the House, after being hospitalized for Covid-19. He was also undergoing cancer treatments.
